revisions.rev:
{{Infobox NFL_season | logo = | team = Miami Dolphins | year = 2009 | record = 7â9 | division_place = 3rd [[AFC East]] | coach = [[Tony Sparano]] | general manager = [[Jeff Ireland]] | stadium = [[Land Shark Stadium]] | playoffs = ''did not qualify'' | pro bowlers = [[Yeremiah Bell]], [[Dan Carpenter]], [[Jake Long]] | AP All-pros = Jake Long ''(2nd team)'' | uniform = Image:AFCE-Uniform-MIA.PNG }} The '''[[2009 NFL season|2009]] [[Miami Dolphins]] season''' was the organization's 40th season in the [[National Football League]] and 44th overall.{{cite web | title = Miami Dolphins History | work = NFL-History.com | url = http://www.nfl-history.com/dolphins.php | accessdate = 4 January 2009 }} The Dolphins entered the 2009 season as the reigning [[American Football Conference East Division|AFC East]] champions after posting an 11â5 record in [[2008 Miami Dolphins season|2008]]. Dropping four more games in 2009, they failed to make the playoffs, marking the 25th consecutive year that the region hosting the Super Bowl would not see its host team play in ithttp://beatthesportsbook.com/home/?p=10901http://www.miamiherald.com/sports/columnists/greg_cote/story/822086.html (not counting, of course, the years where Super Bowls have been played on neutral sites). {{TOClimit|limit=3}} ==Offseason personnel moves== ===Coaching staff=== The Dolphins fired [[offensive line]] coach [[Mike Maser]] on January 14, 2009, just one year after he was hired to [[head coach]] [[Tony Sparano]]'s staff.{{cite web | title = Sources: Dolphins fire O-line coach | work = ProFootballWeekly.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3833043 | accessdate = 14 January 2008 }} During Maser's lone season with the Dolphins, the team had the 12th-best offensive in the league with 345.6 yards per game. A day after firing Maser, the team hired [[Dave DeGuglielmo]], who had been the assistant offensive line coach for the [[New York Giants]], as their new offensive line coach.{{cite web | title = Dolphins Name Dave DeGuglielmo Offensive Line Coach | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=6323 |accessdate=15 January 2008}} After kicking coach [[Steve Hoffman (American football)|Steve Hoffman]] left the team to join the [[Kansas City Chiefs]],{{cite web | title = Chiefs Announce Assistant Coaches, Without Disclosing Their Specific Jobs | work = ProFootballTalk.com | url = http://www.profootballtalk.com/2009/02/17/chiefs-announce-assistant-coaches-without-disclosing-their-specific-jobs/ |accessdate=23 March 2008}} the Dolphins hired [[University of Rhode Island]] head coach [[Darren Rizzi]] as the assistant special teams coach on February 21.{{cite web | title = Dolphins Add Darren Rizzi To Coaching Staff | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=6347&lid=6347 |accessdate=23 March 2008}} ===Players=== ====Re-signings==== *'''January 5''' â Re-signed wide receiver [[Anthony Armstrong (American football)|Anthony Armstrong]], cornerback [[Scorpio Babers]], cornerback [[Will Billingsley]], fullback [[Chris Brown (fullback)|Chris Brown]], defensive tackle [[Joe Cohen]], running back [[Lex Hilliard]] and wide receiver [[Todd Lowber]].{{cite web | title = Miami Dolphins January 2009 transactions | work = ProFootballWeekly.com | url = http://www.profootballweekly.com/PFW/NFL/AFC/AFC+East/Miami/Transactions/2008/transjan.htm | accessdate = 12 January 2008 }} *'''February 20''' â Re-signed offensive tackle [[Vernon Carey]]. *'''February 25''' â Re-signed linebacker [[Channing Crowder]]. *'''February 27''' â Re-signed safety [[Yeremiah Bell]]. *'''May 16''' â Signed fullback [[Lousaka Polite]] to a multi-year extension. *'''May 26''' â Signed cornerback [[Will Allen (cornerback)|Will Allen]] to a multi-year extension. *'''June 22''' â Signed safety [[Tyrone Culver]] to a multi-year extension. ====Signings==== *'''January 6''' â Claimed linebacker [[Tearrius George]] off waivers from the [[New Orleans Saints]]. *'''January 19''' â Signed safety [[Ethan Kilmer]] ([[Cincinnati Bengals|Bengals]]) and linebacker [[Cameron Wake]] ([[BC Lions]]). *'''February 25''' â Signed safety [[Gibril Wilson]] ([[Oakland Raiders|Raiders]]). *'''February 27''' â Signed guard [[Joe Berger]] ([[Dallas Cowboys|Cowboys]]). *'''March 3''' â Signed center [[Jake Grove]] ([[Oakland Raiders|Raiders]]). *'''March 12''' â Signed cornerback [[Eric Green (cornerback)|Eric Green]] ([[Arizona Cardinals|Cardinals]]). *'''April 25''' â Signed punter [[Jy Bond]] ([[Australia]]). *'''May 13''' â Signed linebacker [[Jason Taylor (American football)|Jason Taylor]] ([[Washington Redskins|Redskins]]). ====Departures==== *'''February 10''' â Waived guard [[Matt McChesney]] and linebacker [[Kelvin Smith]]. *'''March 2''' â Terminated the contract of defensive end [[Vonnie Holliday]]. *'''April 27''' â Released quarterback [[John Beck (American football)|John Beck]]. *'''June 1''' â Released wide receiver [[Todd Lowber]]. *'''June 15''' â Released cornerback [[Scorpio Babers]] and punter [[Jy Bond]]. ====Trades==== *'''March 19''' â Acquired defensive tackle [[Tony McDaniel]] from the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] in exchange for seventh-round pick in the [[2009 NFL Draft]]. *'''March 23''' â Traded center [[Samson Satele]] to the [[Oakland Raiders]] in exchange for a sixth-round pick and a swap of fourth-round picks in the [[2009 NFL Draft]]. ====Free agents==== ''UFA'': [[Unrestricted free agent]], ''RFA'': [[Restricted free agent]], ''ERFA'': [[Exclusive-rights free agent]] {| class="wikitable" !Position || Player || Free agency
status || Date signed || 2009 team |-style="background: #ddffdd;" align="center" | SS || [[Yeremiah Bell]] || UFA || 2/26|| [[Miami Dolphins]] |-style="background: #ddffdd;" align="center" | OT || [[Vernon Carey]] || UFA || 2/20|| [[Miami Dolphins]] |-style="background: #ddffdd;" align="center" | LB || [[Channing Crowder]] || UFA || 2/25|| [[Miami Dolphins]] |-style="background: #ffddoo;" align="center" | CB || [[AndrÃ© Goodman]] || UFA || 3/1|| [[Denver Broncos]] |-style="background: #ffddoo;" align="center" | TE || [[Aaron Halterman]] || ERFA || || |-style="background: #ffddoo;" align="center" | FS || [[Renaldo Hill]] || UFA || 2/27|| [[Denver Broncos]] |-style="background: #ffddoo;" align="center" | C || [[Al Johnson (American football)|Al Johnson]] || UFA || 3/17 || [[New England Patriots]] |-style="background: #ddffdd;" align="center" | LB || [[Quentin Moses]] || ERFA || 3/31 || [[Miami Dolphins]] |-style="background: #ddffdd;" align="center" | G || [[Ike Ndukwe]] || ERFA || 3/20 || [[Miami Dolphins]] |-style="background: #ffddoo;" align="center" | WR || [[Tab Perry]] || UFA || || |-style="background: #ffddoo;" align="center" | LB || [[Derek Smith (linebacker)|Derek Smith]] || UFA || || |} {| |- | style="background-color:#ddffdd; border:1px solid #aaaaaa; width:2em;" | | = Retained by Dolphins |} ====2009 NFL Draft==== Originally slated to have the 26th overall pick in the [[2009 NFL Draft]], the Dolphins' pick moved up one spot to 25th after the [[Arizona Cardinals]] and [[Philadelphia Eagles]] made it to the [[NFL playoffs, 2008-09#NFC: Philadelphia Eagles at Arizona Cardinals|NFC Championship]].{{cite web | title = Miami Dolphins move up to no. 25 in draft | work = Sun-Sentinel.com | url = http://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/other/sfl-flspdolphins13sbjan13,0,63657.story | accessdate = 14 January 2008 }} Both the Cardinals (9â7) and Eagles (9â6â1) were projected to pick before the Dolphins (11â5), but with one guaranteed to make the [[Super Bowl XLIII|Super Bowl]] (and thus pick 31st or 32nd depending on the outcome) the Dolphins moved up one position in the draft. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" |- ! colspan="2" | Draft !! rowspan="2" | Name !! rowspan="2" | Position !! rowspan="2" | College !! rowspan="2" | Height !! rowspan="2" | Weight |- ! Rnd !! Pick |- ! 1 !! 25 | [[Vontae Davis]] || [[Cornerback|CB]] || [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign|Illinois]] || 5'11" || 203 |- ! rowspan="2" | 2 !! 44 | [[Pat White (American football)|Pat White]] || [[Quaterback|QB]]/[[Wide Receiver|WR]]|| [[West Virginia University|West Virginia]] || 6'0" || 197 |- ! 61 | [[Sean Smith (cornerback)|Sean Smith]] || CB || [[University of Utah|Utah]] || 6'4" || 215 |- ! 3 !! 87 | [[Patrick Turner]] || [[Wide Receiver|WR]] || [[University of Southern California|USC]] || 6'5" || 220 |- ! 4 !! 108 | [[Brian Hartline]] || WR || [[Ohio State University|Ohio State]]|| 6'3" || 188 |- ! rowspan="2" | 5 !! 161 | [[John Nalbone]] || [[Tight End|TE]] || [[Monmouth University|Monmouth]] || 6'4" || 255 |- ! 165 | [[Chris Clemons (safety)|Chris Clemons]] || [[Free Safety|FS]] || [[Clemson University|Clemson]] || 6'1" || 210 |- ! 6 !! 181 | [[Andrew Gardner (American football)|Andrew Gardner]]|| [[Offensive tackle|OT]] || [[Georgia Institute of Technology|Georgia Tech]] || 6'6" || 305 |- ! 7 !! 214 | [[J. D. Folsom]]|| [[Linebacker#3-4 defense|ILB]] || [[Weber State University|Weber State]] || 6'3" || 230 |- |} '''Notes''' *The Dolphins acquired [[Washington Redskins|Washington's]] 2009 second-round pick when they traded [[defensive end]] [[Jason Taylor (American football)|Jason Taylor]] in July 2008.{{cite web | title = Miami Dolphins July 2008 transactions | work = ProFootballWeekly.com | url = http://www.profootballweekly.com/PFW/NFL/AFC/AFC+East/Miami/Transactions/2008/transjuly.htm | accessdate = 14 January 2008 }} *The Dolphins traded their 2009 sixth-round pick to the [[Dallas Cowboys]] when they acquired [[defensive tackle]] [[Jason Ferguson]] in February 2008.{{cite web | title = Cowboys deal Ferguson to Miami | work = SeattlePI.com | url = http://www.seattlepi.com/scorecard/nflnews.asp?articleID=227610 | accessdate = 14 January 2008 }} *The Dolphins acquired [[Cleveland Browns|Cleveland's]] 2009 seventh-round pick when they traded [[cornerback]] [[Travis Daniels]] in August 2008.{{cite web | title = Miami Dolphins August 2008 transactions | work = ProFootballWeekly.com | url = http://www.profootballweekly.com/PFW/NFL/AFC/AFC+East/Miami/Transactions/2008/transaug.htm | accessdate = 14 January 2008 }} *The Dolphins acquired [[Carolina Panthers|Carolina's]] 2009 seventh-round pick when they traded [[quarterback]] [[Josh McCown]] in August 2008. *The Dolphins traded its second-round selection (56th overall) to [[Indianapolis Colts|Indianapolis]] for their second- and fifth-round selection (61st and 165th overall, respectively). *The Dolphins traded their second 2009 seventh-round selection (237th pick) to [[Kansas City Chiefs|Kansas City]] for a 2010 seventh-round selection. ====Draft pick signings==== *'''May 21''' â Signed tight end [[John Nalbone]] to a four-year contract. *'''June 18''' â Signed offensive tackle [[Andrew Gardner (American football)|Andrew Gardner]] to a four-year contract. *'''July 3''' â Signed wide receiver [[Patrick Turner]] to a four-year contract. *'''July 3''' â Signed linebacker [[J. D. Folsom]] to a four-year contract. *'''July 15''' â Signed wide receiver [[Brian Hartline]] to a four-year contract. *'''July 24''' â Signed cornerback [[Sean Smith (cornerback)|Sean Smith]] to a four-year contract. *'''August 1''' â Signed cornerback [[Vontae Davis]] to a five-year contract. *'''August 2''' â Signed quarterback [[Pat White (American football)|Pat White]] to a four-year contract. *'''August 2''' â Signed safety [[Chris Clemons (safety)|Chris Clemons]] to a four-year contract. ====Undrafted free agents==== Following the [[2009 NFL Draft]], the Dolphins signed the following nine [[undrafted free agent]]s on April 30: {| |valign="top"| * DE [[Ryan Baker (American football)|Ryan Baker]] ([[Purdue Boilermakers football|Purdue]]) * TE [[Jared Bronson]] ([[Central Washington University#Athletics|Central Washington]]) * NT [[Louis Ellis]] ([[Shaw University#Athletics|Shaw]]) * RB [[Anthony Kimble]] ([[Stanford Cardinal football|Stanford]]) * OG [[Mark Lewis (offensive lineman)|Mark Lewis]] ([[Oregon Ducks football|Oregon]]) |valign="top"| * WR [[Brennan Marion]] ([[Tulsa Golden Hurricane football|Tulsa]]) * DE [[Orion Martin]] ([[Virginia Tech Hokies football|Virginia Tech]]) * OT [[SirVincent Rogers]] ([[Houston Cougars football|Houston]]) * WR [[Chris Williams (wide receiver)|Chris Williams]] ([[New Mexico State Aggies football|New Mexico State]]) |} The team later signed guard [[J. D. Quinn]] ([[Montana Grizzlies football|Montana]]) on May 11. Two of the undrafted rookies would end up leaving the team shortly after signing, with Bronson failing to report to training camp on August 2 and Rogers opting for retirement on August 6. ==Training camp and preseason== ===Opening camp roster=== {| class="toccolours" style="text-align: left;" |- ! colspan="9" style="background-color: #006666; color: white; text-align: center;"|'''Miami Dolphins [[Image:Injury icon.svg|7px]] ''Rookies in italics''
|} ===Transactions=== *'''August 2''' â Waived guard [[J. D. Quinn]] and placed tight end [[Jared Bronson]] on the Reserve/Did Not Report list. *'''August 4''' â Placed linebacker [[Matt Roth]] on the Active/Non-Football Injury list. *'''August 5''' â Waived/injured wide receiver [[Brennan Marion]]. *'''August 6''' â Waived fullback [[Chris Brown (fullback)|Chris Brown]] and signed fullback [[Matt Quillen]]. *'''August 6''' â Placed wide receiver [[Brennan Marion]] on [[injured reserve]]. and offensive tackle [[SirVincent Rogers]] on the Reserve/Retired list. *'''August 10''' â Waived fullback [[Matt Quillen]] and signed wide receiver [[James Robinson (gridiron football)|James Robinson]] and placekicker [[Connor Barth]]. *'''August 11''' â Signed fullback [[Joe Kowalewski]]. *'''August 12''' â Placed safety [[Ethan Kilmer]] on the Commissioner's Exemption list. *'''August 19''' â Released cornerback [[Eric Green (cornerback)|Eric Green]]. *'''August 19''' â Moved safety [[Ethan Kilmer]] to the Reserve/Left Squad list. *'''August 24''' â Waived running back [[Anthony Kimble]], nose tackle [[Joe Cohen]], linebacker [[Tearrius George]] and linebacker [[Orion Martin]]. *'''August 24''' â Waived/injured wide receiver [[Chris Williams (wide receiver)|Chris Williams]]. *'''August 24''' â Traded offensive lineman [[Andy Alleman]] and [[Ikechuku Ndukwe]] to the [[Kansas City Chiefs]] in exchange for an undisclosed [[2010 NFL Draft]] pick. *'''August 25''' â Released wide receiver [[Chris Williams (wide receiver)|Chris Williams]] with an injury settlement. *'''August 29''' â Waived wide receiver [[Anthony Armstrong (American football)|Anthony Armstrong]], nose tackle [[Louis Ellis]] and placekicker [[Connor Barth]]. *'''August 29''' â Waived/injured fullback [[Joe Kowalewski]]. *'''September 1''' â Placed fullback [[Joe Kowalewski]] on [[injured reserve]]. *'''September 5''' â Waived or released safety [[Courtney Bryan]], offensive tackle [[Brandon Frye]], linebacker [[William Kershaw]], wide receiver [[Brandon London]], cornerback [[Joey Thomas]], defensive end [[Rodrique Wright]], offensive tackle [[Nate Garner]], cornerback [[Will Billingsley]], defensive end 17 | January 3 | 1:00 pm | [[2009 Pittsburgh Steelers season|Pittsburgh Steelers]] | '''L''' 24â30 | 7â9 | LandShark Stadium | CBS | [http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2010010306/2009/REG17/steelers@dolphins Recap] |- |} ===Standings=== {{2009 AFC East standings}} ===Game results=== ====Week 1: at Atlanta Falcons==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Dolphins |R1=0||R2=0||R3=0||R4=7||RT=7 |Home='''Falcons''' |H1=0||H2=10||H3=6||H4=3||HT=19 |stadium= [[Georgia Dome]], [[Atlanta, Georgia]] |time= 1:00 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= None (Domed Stadium) |attendance= 67,606 |referee= [[Walt Coleman]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Greg Gumbel]] & [[Dan Dierdorf]] }} [[Image:2009 Miami Dolphins.jpg|thumb|right|The Miami Dolphins preparing for the 2009 season opener in Atlanta.]] After a great season for the [[Miami Dolphins]] in 2008, the Dolphins went to the Georgia Dome to take on 2008 playoff contenders, the [[Atlanta Falcons]]. After a scoreless first quarter, the Falcons got on the board with a 1-yard touchdown pass from [[Matt Ryan]] to fullback [[Ovie Mughelli]] in the second quarter. They also got a 36-yard field goal by kicker [[Jason Elam]] to make the score 10â0 at halftime. In the third quarter, [[Mike Peterson]] intercepted a [[Chad Pennington]] pass, which set up a 20-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Tony Gonzalez (American football)|Tony Gonzalez]] and a 50-yard field goal by Jason Elam to make the score 19â0. Chad Pennington then hit a 9-yard touchdown pass to [[Ricky Williams]]. The Falcons won the game 19â7. In 2008, no other team turned the ball over less than the Dolphins with only 13 turnovers, but in Week 1 Miami's offense had 4 turnovers, without having a single turnover on defense. ====Week 2: vs. Indianapolis Colts==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Colts''' |R1=7||R2=6||R3=0||R4=14||RT=27 |Home=Dolphins |H1=7||H2=6||H3=0||H4=10||HT=23 |stadium= [[Land Shark Stadium]], [[Miami Gardens, Florida]] |time= 8:30 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 84 Â°F (Cloudy) |attendance= 66,227 |referee= [[Terry McAulay]] |TV=[[Monday Night Football|ESPN]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Mike Tirico]], [[Ron Jaworski]], [[Jon Gruden]], & [[Suzy Kolber]] }} After a miserable loss to the [[Atlanta Falcons]], the Dolphins host their home opener to the [[Indianapolis Colts]]. On the first play from scrimmage, [[Peyton Manning]] threw an 80-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Dallas Clark]]. The Dolphins answered with a 14-yard touchdown run by [[Ronnie Brown]] out of the [[Wildcat Offense]]. The Dolphins and Colts kept going back and forth at each other with two field goals by [[Dan Carpenter]] and [[Adam Vinatieri]] to make the score 13â13 at halftime. After a scoreless third quarter, Ronnie Brown ran 2-yards for a touchdown to put Miami up 20â13. The Colts answered back with a 15-yard touchdown run by rookie running back [[Donald Brown (American football)|Donald Brown]]. Miami than hit a 45-yard field goal by Dan Carpenter. But the Colts took the lead thanks to a 48-yard touchdown pass to [[Pierre Garcon]]. The Dolphins tried to rally at the end of the game but [[Chad Pennington]] was intercepted by [[Antoine Bethea]] to sucure the Colts victory. The Colts won the game 27â23. The Dolphins dominated the game in the time of possession battle, but lost the game with almost 50 minutes of offensive possession. ====Week 3: at San Diego Chargers==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Dolphins |R1=0||R2=3||R3=3||R4=7||RT=20 |Home='''Chargers''' |H1=0||H2=3||H3=7||H4=13||HT=23 |stadium= [[Qualcomm Stadium]], [[San Diego, California]] |time= 4:15 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 80 Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 67,230 |referee= [[Bill Leavy]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Enberg]] & [[Dan Fouts]] }} Looking for their first win of the season, the Dolphins traveled to [[Qualcomm Stadium]] to take on the [[San Diego Chargers]]. After a scoreless first quarter, [[Nate Kaeding]] hit a 25-yard field goal to score the first points of the game. Miami would answer with a 24-yard field goal to tie the game at halftime 3â3. Miami would then take the lead after a 23-yard field goal by [[Dan Carpenter]]. But the Chargers would retake the lead with a 5-yard touchdoun run by [[Philip Rivers]]. The Chargers would pull away in the fourth quarter with two Nate Kaeding field goals and a 31-yard interception return by safety [[Eric Weddle]]. The Dolphins would get a 14-yard touchdown run by [[Ricky Williams]], but couldn't make a comeback. The Chargers won the game 23â13 Dolphins quarterback [[Chad Pennington]] left the game with a shoulder injury after being hit by linebacker [[Kevin Burnett]] and was out for the season. The Dolphins chose [[Chad Henne]] to lead the Dolphins for the rest of the season. ====Week 4: vs. Buffalo Bills==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Bills |R1=0||R2=3||R3=0||R4=7||RT=10 |Home='''Dolphins''' |H1=0||H2=17||H3=14||H4=7||HT=38 |stadium= [[Land Shark Stadium]], [[Miami Gardens, Florida]] |time= 4:05 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 88 Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 65,523 |referee= [[Carl Cheffers]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Kevin Harlan]] & [[Solomon Wilcots]] }} The [[Miami Dolphins]] came off of a 0â3 start and tried to rebound against the [[Buffalo Bills]]. After a scoreless first quarter the Dolphins rallied quick with a 23-yard interception return for a touchdown by rookie [[Vontae Davis]] and a 1-yard touchdown run by [[Ronnie Brown]] along with a 33-yard field goal by [[Dan Carpenter]] making the halftime score 17â3. Miami would continue with a [[Chad Henne]] touchdown pass to [[Brian Hartline]] and a 1-yard touchdown run by [[Ricky Williams]]. [[Trent Edwards]] would hit [[Josh Reed]] for a 3-yard touchdown but Miami ended the game with a 1-yard touchdown run by Ronnie Brown. The Dolphins won the game 38â10. Chad Henne made his first NFL start and threw for 115 yards and a touchdown. ====Week 5: vs. New York Jets==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Jets |R1=7||R2=6||R3=0||R4=14||RT=0 |Home='''Dolphins''' |Road='''Steelers''' |R1=14||R2=3||R3=7||R4=6|RT= |Home=Dolphins |H1=7||H2=3||H3=0||H4=14|HT= |stadium= [[Land Shark Stadium]], [[Miami Gardens, Florida]] |time= 1:00 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 60 Â°F (Partly Cloudy) |attendance= 70,102 |referee= [[Bill Leavy]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Greg Gumbel]] & [[Dan Dierdorf]] }} The final outcome of this game had somewhat of a [[domino effect]]. It resulted in the Dolphins' elimination from the post-season (including [[Super Bowl XLIV]], which they hosted February 8, 2010), and also, by virtue of the final standings' tiebreaker (as the result of the [[2009 Baltimore Ravens season|Baltimore Ravens]] defeating the [[2009 Oakland Raiders season|Oakland Raiders]]), the Steelers themselves being dethroned of their world title defense. ===Transactions=== ==Staff== {| class="toccolours" style="text-align: left;" |- ! colspan="7" style="background-color: #006666; color: white; text-align: center;"|'''Miami Dolphins 2009 staff''' |- | style="font-size: 95%;" valign="top" | '''Front Office''' *Chairman/Managing General Partner â [[Stephen M.
